words.ENTRY: <H>sand</H><audio>sand.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>a powder consisting of very small grains of rock, found in deserts and on beaches:</D> <X>You need sand to make concrete.</X><dot><X>Wait a minute, I have some sand in my shoe.</X><dot><X>When we go on vacation, all we want is sun, sea, and sand.</X>

Saturdaynouncountable, uncountablethe day of the week after Friday and before Sunday I'm going to see her (on) Saturday.We usually play tennis on Saturdays.They have piano lessons every Saturday.Saturday morning/afternoon/evening/
nightlast/next SaturdayThe museum is open Monday through Saturday, 10 to 4:30.

<H>sauce</H><audio>sauce.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>a thick liquid (that can be hot or cold) that you eat on or with other food:</D> <bracket>countable</bracket><X>The chicken was served in a delicious sauce.</X><dot><bracket>uncountable</bracket><X>tomato sauce</X><dot><X>I opened a jar of spaghetti sauce.</X>

sayverb(third person singular says; past, past participle said) say something (to somebody) to speak words: "Please come back," she said.The teacher said we should hand in our papers by Friday.They just sat there without saying anything.

scarfnouncountable (plural scarfs or scarves) 1.a long thin piece of cloth, usually made of wool, that you wear around your neck to keep warm: He wrapped a scarf around his neck.2.a square piece of cloth that (usually) women wear around their neck or shoulders or over their heads to keep warm or for decoration: She tied a scarf around her neck and went out.

<H>school</H><audio>school.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>the place where children go to be educated:</D> <X>They're building a new school in our area.</X><dot><X>Paula goes to Kennedy High School.</X><dot><X>Do you have to wear a school uniform?</X><dot><X>a public/private school</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>the time you spend at a school; the process of being educated in a school:</D> <X>Children start school at age 5 in the US.</X><dot><X>School starts at 8:30.</X><dot><X>After school we usually have homework to do.</X><NR>3.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a place where you go to learn a particular subject:</D> <X>a driving school</X><dot><X>a language school</X><NR>4.</NR><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>a college or university:</D> <X>Jack had to pay his own way through school.</X><NR>5.</NR><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>a department of some colleges or universities that teaches a particular subject or group of subjects:</D> <bracket>countable</bracket><X>the School of Arts and Sciences</X><dot><bracket>uncountable</bracket><X>She's in law school.</X>

<H>science</H><audio>science.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>the study of and knowledge about the physical world and natural laws:</D> <X>science and technology</X><dot><X>Modern science has discovered a lot about the origin of life.</X><dot><X>a science teacher</X> (= one who teaches biology, chemistry, or physics) <NR>2.</NR><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>one of the subjects into which science can be divided:</D> <bracket>countable</bracket><X>Biology, chemistry, and physics are all sciences.</X>

seeverb(past saw; past participle seen) 1.to become aware of something, using your eyes: It was so dark that we couldn't see.I just saw a rat!2.to look at or watch a movie, play, television program, etc.: Did you see that program on alligators on TV last night?Have you seen Spielberg's new movie yet?

<H>select</H><audio>select.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><D>to choose somebody/something from a number of similar things:</D> <X>You can select whatever you want from the prizes on display.</X><dot><X>The best candidates will be selected to interview for the job.</X>

sendverb(past, past participle sent) send something/somebody (to somebody/something); send (somebody) something to cause something/somebody to go or to be taken somewhere without going there yourself: to send a letter/an e-mailto send a message to somebodyDon't forget to send me a postcard.

sentencenouncountable (grammar) a group of words containing a subject and a verb, that expresses a statement, a question, etc. When a sentence is written, it begins with a capital letter and ends with a period: a grammatically correct sentence

<H>share</H><audio>share.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><NR>1.</NR><CF>share something (with somebody)</CF> <D>to tell somebody about something; to allow somebody to know something:</D> <X>Sometimes it helps to share your problems.</X><NR>2.</NR><CF>share (something) (with somebody)</CF> <D>to have, use, do, or pay something together with another person or other people; to have something that somebody else also has:</D> <X>I share an apartment with four other people.</X><dot><X>There's only one room available, so we'll have to share.</X><dot><X>We share the same interests.</X><NR>3.</NR><CF>share (something) (with somebody)</CF> <D>to let somebody else have or use something that you have:</D> <X>I shared my sandwich with Kim at lunch.</X>

<H>she</H><audio>she.mp3</audio><PS>pronoun</PS><D>(the subject of a verb) the female person or animal who has already been mentioned or is being observed now:</D> <X>"What does your sister do?" "She's a dentist."</X><dot><X>I asked her a question, but she didn't answer.</X><dot><X>Look at her. Isn't she beautiful?</X>

<H>shoe</H><audio>shoe.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a type of covering for the foot, usually made of leather or plastic:</D> <X>a pair of shoes</X><dot><X>What size shoes do you wear?</X><dot><X>I tried on a nice pair of shoes, but they didn't fit.</X>

<H>shop</H><su>1</su><audio>shop.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a small store which usually sells only one type of product:</D> <X>a gift shop</X><H>shop</H><su>2</su><audio>shop.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS>(<DR>shopping</DR>; <DR>shopped</DR>) <D>to go to a store or stores in order to buy things:</D> <X>I prefer to shop on my own.</X><dot><X>He's shopping for some new clothes.</X><dot><X>We go shopping every Saturday.</X>

<H>short</H><audio>short.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>not measuring much from one end to the other; not long:</D> <X>a short line</X><dot><X>a short distance</X><dot><X>short hair</X><NR>2.</NR><D>less than the average height; not tall:</D> <X>a short, fat man</X><NR>3.</NR><D>not lasting a long time:</D> <X>a short visit</X><dot><X>She left a short time ago.</X>

<H>show</H><audio>show.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a program on television or on the radio:</D> <X>There's a show I want to see tonight.</X><dot><X>my favorite TV show</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a play in a theater:</D> <X>a Broadway show</X>
shrimpnouncountable (plural shrimp or shrimps) a small sea creature with a shell that turns pink when you cook it

sickadjectivenot in good health; not well; ill: a sick child
I was sick last week and missed three days of school.
<H>simply</H><audio>simply.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><D>only; just:</D> <X>Don't get mad. The whole problem is simply a misunderstanding.</X>

singverb(past sang; past participle sung) to make musical sounds with the voice: He always sings when he's in the shower.The birds were singing outside my window.She sang all her most popular songs at the concert.
<H>singer</H><audio>singer.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a person who sings, especially in public:</D> <X>My favorite singer is Mariah Carey.</X>

<H>sister</H><audio>sister.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a girl or woman who has the same parents as another person:</D> <X>I have one brother and two sisters.</X><dot><X>We're sisters.</X><dot><X>Keisha is my sister.</X>

sitverb(present participle sitting; past, past participle sat) 1.to be in a position on a chair, etc. in which the upper part of your body is upright and your weight is supported at the bottom of your back: We sat in the back yard all afternoon.She was sitting on the sofa, talking to her mother.Just sit still and behave yourself!2.sit (down) to lower the body into the position of sitting: Come and sit next to me. I want to talk to you.
<H>sizzle</H><audio>sizzle.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><D>to make the sound of food frying in hot fat:</D> <X>I could hear the bacon sizzling in the kitchen.</X>

ski1nouncountableone of a pair of long, flat, narrow pieces of wood, metal, or plastic that are fastened to boots and used for moving over snow: a pair of skisski2verb(present participle skiing; past, past participle skied) to move over snow on skis: When did you learn to ski?They go skiing in the mountains every winter.
<H>skirt</H><audio>skirt.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a piece of clothing that is worn by women and girls and that hangs down from the waist:</D> <X>a short skirt</X>
<H>skyscraper</H><audio>skyscraper.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a very tall building</D> <dot><X>The Empire State Building in New York City is a famous skyscraper.</X>

smalladjective1.not large in size, number, amount, etc.:
a small car/apartment/towna small group of people2.not important or serious; slight: Don't worry. It's only a small problem.

<H>smart</H><audio>smart.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>intelligent; able to learn and think quickly:</D> <X>He's not smart enough to be a politician.</X><dot><X>a very smart little girl</X><NR>2.</NR><D>showing good judgment or resulting from quick thinking:</D> <X>a smart decision</X>
<H>sneaker</H><audio>sneaker.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a type of comfortable shoe that you wear to play sports or with informal clothes:</D> <X>a pair of sneakers</X>

so1conjunction1.with the result that; therefore: She felt very tired, so she went to bed early.2.(used to introduce a new topic into a conversation): So, Jason, how's it going in school?so2adverb1.(used to emphasize an adjective or adverb, especially when there is a particular result) to the extent (that); to a great degree: She's so sick (that) she can't get out of bed.He was driving so fast that he couldn't stop.So many people came to the concert that some couldn't get in.2.(informal) very: You've been so nice. How can I thank you?Rob is so cute!Thanks so much!

<H>soccer</H><audio>soccer.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>a game that is played by two teams of eleven players who try to kick a round ball into a goal:</D> <X>a soccer game</X>

<H>some</H><audio>some.mp3</audio><PS>determiner;</PS> <PS>pronoun</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>a certain amount or number:</D> <X>We need some butter and some potatoes.</X><dot><X>I don't need any more money; I've still got some.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>(used in questions when you expect or want the answer "yes"):</D> <X>Would you like some more cake?</X><dot><X>Can I take some of this paper?</X><NR>3.</NR><D>(used when you are referring to certain members of a group or certain types of a thing and not all of them):</D> <X>Some students enjoy this kind of work; some don't.</X><dot><X>Some of his books are very exciting.</X>

<H>somebody</H><audio>somebody.mp3</audio><PS>pronoun</PS><D>a person (not known or not mentioned by name); someone:</D> <X>How are you? Somebody said that you were sick.</X><dot><X>She's getting married to somebody she met at work.</X><dot><X>There's somebody at the door.</X>
someday (also some day) adverbat some time in the future: I hope you'll come and visit me someday.

<H>someone</H><audio>someone.mp3</audio><PS>pronoun</PS><D>a person (not known or not mentioned by name); somebody:</D> <X>How are you? Someone said that you were sick.</X><dot><X>She's getting married to someone she met at work.</X><dot><X>There's someone at the door.</X>

<H>something</H><audio>something.mp3</audio><PS>pronoun</PS><D>a thing that is not known or not named:</D> <X>I've got something in my eye.</X><dot><X>Wait a minute! I forgot something.</X><dot><X>Let's get something to eat.</X><dot><X>I have something important to tell you.</X>

<H>sometimes</H><audio>sometimes.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><D>on some occasions; now and then:</D> <X>Sometimes I drive to work and sometimes I take the bus.</X><dot><X>I sometimes watch TV in the evenings.</X>

<H>soon</H><audio>soon.mp3</audio><PS>adverb</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>not long after the present time or the time mentioned:</D> <X>It will soon be dark.</X><dot><X>He left soon after me.</X><dot><X>We should arrive at your house soon after twelve.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>early; quickly:</D> <X>Don't leave so soon. Stay for dinner.</X><dot><X>How soon can you get here?</X>

sorry1interjection1.(used for apologizing, making excuses, etc.): Sorry, I didn't see you standing behind me.Sorry I'm late. The bus didn't come on time.2.(used for asking somebody to repeat something you did not hear correctly): "My name's Maggie Wiseman." "Sorry? Maggie who?"sorry2adjective(sorrier; sorriest) 1.(not before a noun) sorry (for/about something); sorry (to do something/
that ...) (used for apologizing for something that you have done): I'm sorry I kept you all waiting.I'm sorry to be so late.2.(not before a noun) sorry (to do something/that ...); sorry (for/about something) sad or disappointed: I was sorry to miss you on Saturday.I was sorry not to get the job.

<H>sound</H><su>1</su><audio>sound.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>countable</bracket><D>something that you hear or that can be heard:</D> <X>the sound of voices</X><dot><X>She opened the door without a sound.</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>what you hear; impressions received by hearing:</D> <X>Light travels faster than sound.</X><dot><X>sound waves</X><H>sound</H><su>2</su><audio>sound.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><D>to give a particular impression when heard or heard about; to seem:</D> <X>That sounds like a child crying.</X><dot><X>The rain sounds heavy.</X><dot><X>You sound like my mother!</X>
<H>soup</H><audio>soup.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>liquid food made by cooking meat, vegetables, etc. in water:</D> <X>chicken soup</X><dot><X>a can of soup</X>

<H>soy sauce</H><audio>soy_sauce.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>a dark brown sauce that is made from soybeans and that you add to food, especially Chinese or Japanese food</D>
<H>soybean</H><audio>soybean.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a type of bean that can be used to make food products such as artificial meat and milk</D>

spellverb(past, past participle spelled or spelt) to write or say the letters of a word in the correct order: I never learned to spell very well in school.How do you spell your last name?
His name is spelled P-H-I-L-I-P.

spend (past, past participle spent) 1.spend (something) (for/on something) to give or pay money for something: How much do you spend on food each week?You can't keep on spending so much money!2.to pass time: I spent a whole evening writing letters.I'm spending the weekend at my parents' house.He spent two years in Rome.
<H>spicy</H><audio>spicy.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS>(<DR>spicier</DR>; <DR>spiciest</DR>) <D>containing spice (usually with a strong or hot taste):</D> <X>Mexican food is very spicy.</X>

<H>sport</H><audio>sport.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>a physical game or activity that you do for exercise or because you enjoy it:</D> <X>Soccer is my favorite sport.</X><dot><X>John played a lot of sports when he was in high school.</X><dot><X>an Olympic sport</X>

<H>spring</H><audio>spring.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>the season of the year which follows winter and comes before summer. In spring the weather gets warmer and plants begin to grow.:</D> <bracket>countable</bracket><X>a cold, wet spring</X><dot><X>in the spring of 2004</X><dot><bracket>uncountable</bracket><X>There's a feeling of spring in the air.</X>

<H>square</H><audio>square.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>an open space in a town or city that has buildings all around it:</D> <X>Times Square in New York City</X><dot><X>the market square</X>
squishverb(informal) 1.if something soft squishes or is squished, it is crushed out of shape when it is pressed 2.to make a soft wet sucking sound: Her wet sneakers squished at every step.

<H>start</H><audio>start.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><NR>1.</NR><CF>start (something/to do something/doing something)</CF> <D>to begin doing something:</D> <X>Turn over your test papers and start now.</X><dot><X>What time do you have to start work in the morning?</X><dot><X>After waiting for an hour, the customers started to complain.</X><dot><X>She started playing the piano when she was six.</X><NR>2.</NR><D>to begin to happen or to make something begin to happen:</D> <X>What time does the concert start?</X><dot><X>I'd like to start the meeting now.</X><dot><X>The fight started when the boys were leaving the club.</X>

starveverbto suffer very badly or die from hunger; to make somebody/something suffer or die in this way: Millions of people are starving in the poorer countries of the world.That winter many animals starved to death. be starving; be starved (informal) to be extremely hungry: When will dinner be ready? I'm starving!

<H>station</H><audio>station.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><NR>1.</NR><D>a building or structure along a road, railroad track, etc. where buses, trains, etc. stop so that passengers can get on and off:</D> <X>a railroad/train/bus/subway station</X><NR>2.</NR><D>a building where a particular service or activity is based:</D> <X>a gas station</X><dot><X>a police station</X>

<H>statue</H><audio>statue.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a figure of a person or animal, that is made of stone or metal and usually put in a public place:</D> <X>Michelangelo's statue of David</X>

<H>stay</H><audio>stay.mp3</audio><PS>verb</PS><NR>1.</NR><D>to be somewhere as a visitor or guest:</D> <X>We stayed with friends in Boston.</X><dot><X>to stay at a hotel</X><dot><X>Can you stay for lunch?</X><NR>2.</NR><D>to continue to be somewhere and not go away:</D> <X>Sara stayed in bed until 11 o'clock.</X><dot><X>I can't stay long.</X><dot><X>Stay on this road until you get to Wells Street.</X><NR>3.</NR><D>to continue to be in a particular state or situation without change:</D> <X>I can't stay awake any longer.</X>

<H>store</H><audio>store.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a building or part of a building where things are bought and sold:</D> <X>a furniture store</X><dot><X>Can you go to the store and pick up some bread and milk?</X>
<H>straight</H><audio>straight.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>not bent or curved:</D> <X>a straight line</X><dot><X>straight hair</X> (= not curly)

<H>street</H><audio>street.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><NR>1.</NR><D>a road in a town or city that has stores, houses, etc. on one or both sides:</D> <X>to walk along/down the street</X><dot><X>to cross the street</X><dot><X>Don't stand in the street. You'll get hit by a car!</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>singular</bracket><D>(used in names of streets):</D> <X>to go shopping on Main Street</X><dot><X>264 Chestnut St.</X>

studentnouncountablea person who is studying at a school, college, or university: Julia is a medical student at Harvard.
a part-time college studentAshley wasn't a very good student in high school.
studionouncountable (plural studios) a room where an artist or photographer works or performers practice: a photographer's studioa dance studio

studyverb(present participle studying; third person singular studies; past, past participle studied) to spend time learning about something: Lawrence has been studying hard for his final exams.to study French in school
<H>stylish</H><audio>stylish.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>fashionable and attractive</D>
<H>subway</H><audio>subway.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>an underground train system in a city:</D> <X>Kristi rides the subway to work every day.</X>

<H>such</H><audio>such.mp3</audio><PS>determiner</PS><D>(used for emphasizing the degree of something):</D> <X>It was such a boring movie that I fell asleep.</X><dot><X>Let's have lunch outdoors. It's such a nice day.</X>

<H>suit</H><audio>suit.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a set of clothes that are made of the same material and that are fairly formal. A man's suit usually consists of a jacket and pants, and a woman's suit of a jacket and a skirt or pants:</D> <X>Businesspeople usually wear suits.</X>

<H>summer</H><audio>summer.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>the hottest season of the year, after spring and before fall:</D> <bracket>uncountable</bracket><X>Are you going to the beach this summer?</X><dot><X>a summer job</X><dot><X>summer vacation</X>
<H>summertime</H><audio>summertime.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>the season of summer:</D> <X>It's busy here in the summertime.</X>

<H>sun</H><audio>sun.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><NR>1.</NR><bracket>singular</bracket><D>the star that shines in the sky during the day and that gives the earth heat and light:</D> <X>The sun rises in the east and sets in the west.</X><dot><X>the sun's rays</X><NR>2.</NR><bracket>singular, uncountable</bracket><D>light and heat from the sun:</D> <bracket>singular</bracket><X>Don't sit in the sun too long.</X><dot><bracket>uncountable</bracket><X>Too much sun can be harmful.</X>

<H>sunburn</H><audio>sunburn.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>red painful skin that you get after being in strong sunlight for too long:</D> <X>Tom stayed in the sun too long yesterday and got a sunburn.</X>

<H>Sunday</H><audio>Sunday.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable, uncountable</bracket><D>the first day of the week, coming before Monday</D> <X>I'm going to see her (on) Sunday.</X><dot><X>We usually play tennis on Sundays.</X><dot><X>They don't work on Sunday.</X><dot><X>Sunday morning/afternoon/evening/night</X><dot><X>last/next Sunday</X><dot><X>The museum is open Tuesday through Sunday, 10 to 4:30.</X><dot><X>Did you see that article about Italy in Sunday's paper?</X>
<H>sunlight</H><audio>sunlight.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>the light from the sun</D>
sureadverb(informal) (used as an answer to a question) yes; of course: "Can I borrow this book?" "Sure."

<H>sushi</H><audio>sushi.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>a Japanese dish of small cakes of cold cooked rice, flavored with vinegar and served with raw fish, etc. on top:</D> <X>a sushi bar</X>
<H>sweater</H><audio>sweater.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a warm piece of clothing with long sleeves, often made of wool or cotton yarn:</D> <X>a pullover sweater</X>
<H>sweet</H><audio>sweet.mp3</audio><PS>adjective</PS><D>tasting like sugar; not sour or salty:</D> <X>This chocolate is too sweet.</X>

swimverb(present participle swimming; past swam; past participle swum) 1.to move your body through water: How far can you swim?Hundreds of tiny fish swam past.They went swimming before breakfast.2.to cover or cross a distance, etc. by swimming: I swam 25 lengths of the pool.
